column2: Perhaps her words were not just like these, but her thoughts were.
column3: Perhaps her words were not just like these, but her thoughts were.

column2: She took up the child, and carried her home.
column3: She took up the child, and carried her home.

column2: And this is how Rosamond came to occupy the place of the little girl whom she had envied in the picture.
column3: And this is how Rosamond came to occupy the place of the little girl whom she had envied in the picture.

column2: VII.
column3: seven.

column2: Notwithstanding the differences between the two girls, which were, indeed, so many that most people would have said they were not in the least alike, they were the same in this, that each cared more for her own fancies and desires than for any thing else in the world.
column3: Notwithstanding the differences between the two girls, which were, indeed, so many that most people would have said they were not in the least alike, they were the same in this, that each cared more for her own fancies and desires than for any thing else in the world.

column2: But I will tell you another difference: the princess was like several children in one--such was the variety of her moods; and in one mood she had no recollection or care about any thing whatever belonging to a previous mood--not even if it had left her but a moment before, and had been so violent as to make her ready to put her hand in the fire to get what she wanted.
column3: But I will tell you another difference: the princess was like several children in one-such was the variety of her moods; and in one mood she had no recollection or care about any thing whatever belonging to a previous mood-not even if it had left her but a moment before, and had been so violent as to make her ready to put her hand in the fire to get what she wanted.

column2: Plainly she was the mere puppet of her moods, and more than that, any cunning nurse who knew her well enough could call or send away those moods almost as she pleased, like a showman pulling strings behind a show.
column3: Plainly she was the mere puppet of her moods, and more than that, any cunning nurse who knew her well enough could call or send away those moods almost as she pleased, like a showman pulling strings behind a show.

column2: Agnes, on the contrary, seldom changed her mood, but kept that of calm assured self-satisfaction.
column3: Agnes, on the contrary, seldom changed her mood, but kept that of calm assured self satisfaction.

column2: Father nor mother had ever by wise punishment helped her to gain a victory over herself, and do what she did not like or choose; and their folly in reasoning with one unreasonable had fixed her in her conceit.
column3: Father nor mother had ever by wise punishment helped her to gain a victory over herself, and do what she did not like or choose; and their folly in reasoning with one unreasonable had fixed her in her conceit.

column2: She would actually nod her head to herself in complacent pride that she had stood out against them.
column3: She would actually nod her head to herself in complacent pride that she had stood out against them.

column2: This, however, was not so difficult as to justify even the pride of having conquered, seeing she loved them so little, and paid so little attention to the arguments and persuasions they used.
column3: This, however, was not so difficult as to justify even the pride of having conquered, seeing she loved them so little, and paid so little attention to the arguments and persuasions they used.

column2: Neither, when she found herself wrapped in the dark folds of the wise woman's cloak, did she behave in the least like the princess, for she was not afraid.
column3: Neither, when she found herself wrapped in the dark folds of the wise woman's cloak, did she behave in the least like the princess, for she was not afraid.

column2: She'll soon set me down, she said, too self-important to suppose that any one would dare do her an injury.
column3: She'll soon set me down, she said, too self important to suppose that any one would dare do her an injury.

column2: Whether it be a good thing or a bad not to be afraid depends on what the fearlessness is founded upon.
column3: Whether it be a good thing or a bad not to be afraid depends on what the fearlessness is founded upon.

column2: Some have no fear, because they have no knowledge of the danger: there is nothing fine in that.
column3: Some have no fear, because they have no knowledge of the danger: there is nothing fine in that.

column2: Some are too stupid to be afraid: there is nothing fine in that.
column3: Some are too stupid to be afraid: there is nothing fine in that.

column2: Some who are not easily frightened would yet turn their backs and run, the moment they were frightened: such never had more courage than fear.
column3: Some who are not easily frightened would yet turn their backs and run, the moment they were frightened: such never had more courage than fear.

column2: But the man who will do his work in spite of his fear is a man of true courage.
column3: But the man who will do his work in spite of his fear is a man of true courage.

column2: The fearlessness of Agnes was only ignorance: she did not know what it was to be hurt; she had never read a single story of giant, or ogress or wolf; and her mother had never carried out one of her threats of punishment.
column3: The fearlessness of Agnes was only ignorance: she did not know what it was to be hurt; she had never read a single story of giant, or ogress or wolf; and her mother had never carried out one of her threats of punishment.

column2: If the wise woman had but pinched her, she would have shown herself an abject little coward, trembling with fear at every change of motion so long as she carried her.
column3: If the wise woman had but pinched her, she would have shown herself an abject little coward, trembling with fear at every change of motion so long as she carried her.

column2: Nothing such, however, was in the wise woman's plan for the curing of her.
column3: Nothing such, however, was in the wise woman's plan for the curing of her.

column2: On and on she carried her without a word.
column3: On and on she carried her without a word.

column2: She knew that if she set her down she would never run after her like the princess, at least not before the evil thing was already upon her.
column3: She knew that if she set her down she would never run after her like the princess, at least not before the evil thing was already upon her.

column2: On and on she went, never halting, never letting the light look in, or Agnes look out.
column3: On and on she went, never halting, never letting the light look in, or Agnes look out.

column2: She walked very fast, and got home to her cottage very soon after the princess had gone from it.
column3: She walked very fast, and got home to her cottage very soon after the princess had gone from it.

column2: But she did not set Agnes down either in the cottage or in the great hall.
column3: But she did not set Agnes down either in the cottage or in the great hall.

column2: She had other places, none of them alike.
column3: She had other places, none of them alike.

column2: The place she had chosen for Agnes was a strange one--such a one as is to be found nowhere else in the wide world.
column3: The place she had chosen for Agnes was a strange one-such a one as is to be found nowhere else in the wide world.

column2: It was a great hollow sphere, made of a substance similar to that of the mirror which Rosamond had broken, but differently compounded.
column3: It was a great hollow sphere, made of a substance similar to that of the mirror which Rosamond had broken, but differently compounded.

column2: That substance no one could see by itself.
column3: That substance no one could see by itself.

column2: It had neither door, nor window, nor any opening to break its perfect roundness.
column3: It had neither door, nor window, nor any opening to break its perfect roundness.

column2: The wise woman carried Agnes into a dark room, there undressed her, took from her hand her knitting-needles, and put her, naked as she was born, into the hollow sphere.
column3: The wise woman carried Agnes into a dark room, there undressed her, took from her hand her knitting needles, and put her, naked as she was born, into the hollow sphere.

column2: What sort of a place it was she could not tell.
column3: What sort of a place it was she could not tell.

column2: She could see nothing but a faint cold bluish light all about her.
column3: She could see nothing but a faint cold bluish light all about her.

column2: She could not feel that any thing supported her, and yet she did not sink.
column3: She could not feel that any thing supported her, and yet she did not sink.

column2: She stood for a while, perfectly calm, then sat down.
column3: She stood for a while, perfectly calm, then sat down.

column2: Nothing bad could happen to HER--she was so important!
column3: Nothing bad could happen to HER-she was so important!

column2: And, indeed, it was but this: she had cared only for Somebody, and now she was going to have only Somebody.
column3: And, indeed, it was but this: she had cared only for Somebody, and now she was going to have only Somebody.

column2: Her own choice was going to be carried a good deal farther for her than she would have knowingly carried it for herself.
column3: Her own choice was going to be carried a good deal farther for her than she would have knowingly carried it for herself.

column2: After sitting a while, she wished she had something to do, but nothing came.
column3: After sitting a while, she wished she had something to do, but nothing came.

column2: A little longer, and it grew wearisome.
column3: A little longer, and it grew wearisome.

column2: She would see whether she could not walk out of the strange luminous dusk that surrounded her.
column3: She would see whether she could not walk out of the strange luminous dusk that surrounded her.

column2: Walk she found she could, well enough, but walk out she could not.
column3: Walk she found she could, well enough, but walk out she could not.

column2: On and on she went, keeping as much in a straight line as she might, but after walking until she was thoroughly tired, she found herself no nearer out of her prison than before.
column3: On and on she went, keeping as much in a straight line as she might, but after walking until she was thoroughly tired, she found herself no nearer out of her prison than before.

column2: She had not, indeed, advanced a single step; for, in whatever direction she tried to go, the sphere turned round and round, answering her feet accordingly.
column3: She had not, indeed, advanced a single step; for, in whatever direction she tried to go, the sphere turned round and round, answering her feet accordingly.

column2: Like a squirrel in his cage she but kept placing another spot of the cunningly suspended sphere under her feet, and she would have been still only at its lowest point after walking for ages.
column3: Like a squirrel in his cage she but kept placing another spot of the cunningly suspended sphere under her feet, and she would have been still only at its lowest point after walking for ages.

column2: At length she cried aloud; but there was no answer.
column3: At length she cried aloud; but there was no answer.

column2: It grew dreary and drearier--in her, that is: outside there was no change.
column3: It grew dreary and drearier-in her, that is: outside there was no change.

column2: Nothing was overhead, nothing under foot, nothing on either hand, but the same pale, faint, bluish glimmer.
column3: Nothing was overhead, nothing under foot, nothing on either hand, but the same pale, faint, bluish glimmer.

column2: She wept at last, then grew very angry, and then sullen; but nobody heeded whether she cried or laughed.
column3: She wept at last, then grew very angry, and then sullen; but nobody heeded whether she cried or laughed.

column2: It was all the same to the cold unmoving twilight that rounded her.
column3: It was all the same to the cold unmoving twilight that rounded her.

column2: On and on went the dreary hours--or did they go at all?--"no change, no pause, no hope;"--on and on till she FELT she was forgotten, and then she grew strangely still and fell asleep.
column3: On and on went the dreary hours-or did they go at all?--"no change, no pause, no hope;"--on and on till she FELT she was forgotten, and then she grew strangely still and fell asleep.

column2: The moment she was asleep, the wise woman came, lifted her out, and laid her in her bosom; fed her with a wonderful milk, which she received without knowing it; nursed her all the night long, and, just ere she woke, laid her back in the blue sphere again.
column3: The moment she was asleep, the wise woman came, lifted her out, and laid her in her bosom; fed her with a wonderful milk, which she received without knowing it; nursed her all the night long, and, just ere she woke, laid her back in the blue sphere again.

column2: When first she came to herself, she thought the horrors of the preceding day had been all a dream of the night.
column3: When first she came to herself, she thought the horrors of the preceding day had been all a dream of the night.

column2: But they soon asserted themselves as facts, for here they were!--nothing to see but a cold blue light, and nothing to do but see it.
column3: But they soon asserted themselves as facts, for here they were!--nothing to see but a cold blue light, and nothing to do but see it.

column2: Oh, how slowly the hours went by!
column3: Oh, how slowly the hours went by!

column2: She lost all notion of time.
column3: She lost all notion of time.

column2: If she had been told that she had been there twenty years, she would have believed it--or twenty minutes--it would have been all the same: except for weariness, time was for her no more.
column3: If she had been told that she had been there twenty years, she would have believed it-or twenty minutes-it would have been all the same: except for weariness, time was for her no more.

column2: Another night came, and another still, during both of which the wise woman nursed and fed her.
column3: Another night came, and another still, during both of which the wise woman nursed and fed her.

column2: But she knew nothing of that, and the same one dreary day seemed ever brooding over her.
column3: But she knew nothing of that, and the same one dreary day seemed ever brooding over her.

column2: All at once, on the third day, she was aware that a naked child was seated beside her.
column3: All at once, on the third day, she was aware that a naked child was seated beside her.

column2: But there was something about the child that made her shudder.
column3: But there was something about the child that made her shudder.

column2: She never looked at Agnes, but sat with her chin sunk on her chest, and her eyes staring at her own toes.
column3: She never looked at Agnes, but sat with her chin sunk on her chest, and her eyes staring at her own toes.

column2: She was the color of pale earth, with a pinched nose, and a mere slit in her face for a mouth.
column3: She was the color of pale earth, with a pinched nose, and a mere slit in her face for a mouth.

column2: How ugly she is! thought Agnes.
column3: How ugly she is! thought Agnes.

column2: What business has she beside me!
column3: What business has she beside me!

column2: But it was so lonely that she would have been glad to play with a serpent, and put out her hand to touch her.
column3: But it was so lonely that she would have been glad to play with a serpent, and put out her hand to touch her.

column2: She touched nothing.
column3: She touched nothing.

column2: The child, also, put out her hand--but in the direction away from Agnes. And that was well, for if she had touched Agnes it would have killed her.
column3: The child, also, put out her hand-but in the direction away from Agnes. And that was well, for if she had touched Agnes it would have killed her.

column2: Then Agnes said, "Who are you?" And the little girl said, "Who are you?"
column3: Then Agnes said, "Who are you?" And the little girl said, "Who are you?"

column2: I am Agnes, said Agnes; and the little girl said, "I am Agnes." Then Agnes thought she was mocking her, and said, "You are ugly;" and the little girl said, "You are ugly."
column3: I am Agnes, said Agnes; and the little girl said, "I am Agnes." Then Agnes thought she was mocking her, and said, "You are ugly;" and the little girl said, "You are ugly."

column2: Then Agnes lost her temper, and put out her hands to seize the little girl; but lo! the little girl was gone, and she found herself tugging at her own hair.
column3: Then Agnes lost her temper, and put out her hands to seize the little girl; but lo! the little girl was gone, and she found herself tugging at her own hair.

column2: She let go; and there was the little girl again!
column3: She let go; and there was the little girl again!

column2: Agnes was furious now, and flew at her to bite her.
column3: Agnes was furious now, and flew at her to bite her.

column2: But she found her teeth in her own arm, and the little girl was gone--only to return again; and each time she came back she was tenfold uglier than before.
column3: But she found her teeth in her own arm, and the little girl was gone-only to return again; and each time she came back she was tenfold uglier than before.

column2: And now Agnes hated her with her whole heart.
column3: And now Agnes hated her with her whole heart.

column2: The moment she hated her, it flashed upon her with a sickening disgust that the child was not another, but her Self, her Somebody, and that she was now shut up with her for ever and ever--no more for one moment ever to be alone.
column3: The moment she hated her, it flashed upon her with a sickening disgust that the child was not another, but her Self, her Somebody, and that she was now shut up with her for ever and ever-no more for one moment ever to be alone.

column2: In her agony of despair, sleep descended, and she slept.
column3: In her agony of despair, sleep descended, and she slept.

column2: When she woke, there was the little girl, heedless, ugly, miserable, staring at her own toes.
column3: When she woke, there was the little girl, heedless, ugly, miserable, staring at her own toes.

column2: All at once, the creature began to smile, but with such an odious, self-satisfied expression, that Agnes felt ashamed of seeing her.
column3: All at once, the creature began to smile, but with such an odious, self satisfied expression, that Agnes felt ashamed of seeing her.

column2: Then she began to pat her own cheeks, to stroke her own body, and examine her finger-ends, nodding her head with satisfaction. Agnes felt that there could not be such another hateful, ape-like creature, and at the same time was perfectly aware she was only doing outside of her what she herself had been doing, as long as she could remember, inside of her.
column3: Then she began to pat her own cheeks, to stroke her own body, and examine her finger ends, nodding her head with satisfaction. Agnes felt that there could not be such another hateful, ape like creature, and at the same time was perfectly aware she was only doing outside of her what she herself had been doing, as long as she could remember, inside of her.

column2: She turned sick at herself, and would gladly have been put out of existence, but for three days the odious companionship went on.
column3: She turned sick at herself, and would gladly have been put out of existence, but for three days the odious companionship went on.

column2: By the third day, Agnes was not merely sick but ashamed of the life she had hitherto led, was despicable in her own eyes, and astonished that she had never seen the truth concerning herself before.
column3: By the third day, Agnes was not merely sick but ashamed of the life she had hitherto led, was despicable in her own eyes, and astonished that she had never seen the truth concerning herself before.

column2: The next morning she woke in the arms of the wise woman; the horror had vanished from her sight, and two heavenly eyes were gazing upon her. She wept and clung to her, and the more she clung, the more tenderly did the great strong arms close around her.
column3: The next morning she woke in the arms of the wise woman; the horror had vanished from her sight, and two heavenly eyes were gazing upon her. She wept and clung to her, and the more she clung, the more tenderly did the great strong arms close around her.

column2: When she had lain thus for a while, the wise woman carried her into her cottage, and washed her in the little well; then dressed her in clean garments, and gave her bread and milk.
column3: When she had lain thus for a while, the wise woman carried her into her cottage, and washed her in the little well; then dressed her in clean garments, and gave her bread and milk.

column2: When she had eaten it, she called her to her, and said very solemnly,--
column3: When she had eaten it, she called her to her, and said very solemnly,--

column2: Agnes, you must not imagine you are cured.	Agnes, you must not imagine you are cured.
column3: true

column2: That you are ashamed of yourself now is no sign that the cause for such shame has ceased.
column3: That you are ashamed of yourself now is no sign that the cause for such shame has ceased.

column2: In new circumstances, especially after you have done well for a while, you will be in danger of thinking just as much of yourself as before.
column3: In new circumstances, especially after you have done well for a while, you will be in danger of thinking just as much of yourself as before.

column2: So beware of yourself.
column3: So beware of yourself.

column2: I am going from home, and leave you in charge of the house.
column3: I am going from home, and leave you in charge of the house.

column2: Do just as I tell you till my return."
column3: Do just as I tell you till my return."

column2: She then gave her the same directions she had formerly given Rosamond--with this difference, that she told her to go into the picture-hall when she pleased, showing her the entrance, against which the clock no longer stood--and went away, closing the door behind her.
column3: She then gave her the same directions she had formerly given Rosamond-with this difference, that she told her to go into the picture hall when she pleased, showing her the entrance, against which the clock no longer stood-and went away, closing the door behind her.
